articles.headline: Wisconsin’s Scott Walker Signs Bills Stripping Powers From Incoming Governor
articles.snippet: Mr. Walker, a Republican who has pushed Wisconsin to the right, signed legislation hobbling his Democratic successor as one of his final acts as governor.
articles.abstract: Mr. Walker, a Republican who has pushed Wisconsin to the right, signed legislation hobbling his Democratic successor as one of his final acts as governor.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOX CROSSING, Wis. — Gov. Scott Walker made a national name for himself in the Republican Party by cutting the power of public sector unions eight years ago, only weeks after he swept into office in Wisconsin. On Friday, he signed legislation to cut the power of the Democrat who defeated him, a final act of a tumultuous tenure that moved Wisconsin firmly to the right.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Monica Davey

articles.headline: The Simplest Annuity Explainer We Could Write
articles.snippet: We define immediate annuities, fixed annuities, variable annuities and index annuities, plus give you questions to ask salespeople.
articles.abstract: We define immediate annuities, fixed annuities, variable annuities and index annuities, plus give you questions to ask salespeople.
articles.lead_paragraph: Annuities can be complicated. This column will not be.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Mueller Rejects Flynn’s Attempt to Portray Himself as Victim of the F.B.I.
articles.snippet: Michael T. Flynn, the president’s former national security adviser, had cooperated with the special counsel, but in asking for leniency, he stoked an unfounded theory about potential evidence he did not lie to investigators.
articles.abstract: Michael T. Flynn, the president’s former national security adviser, had cooperated with the special counsel, but in asking for leniency, he stoked an unfounded theory about potential evidence he did not lie to investigators.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel’s office rejected on Friday a suggestion from Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, that he had been tricked into lying last year to F.B.I. agents investigating Russia’s election interference and ties to Trump associates.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman

articles.headline: How a National Security Investigation of Huawei Set Off an International Incident
articles.snippet: The chief financial officer was arrested after a yearslong American inquiry into the Chinese telecommunications company.
articles.abstract: The chief financial officer was arrested after a yearslong American inquiry into the Chinese telecommunications company.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a message that federal authorities had grown accustomed to hearing: The global bank HSBC belatedly realized it had been processing financial transactions that might have run afoul of American law.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Emily Flitter, Katie Benner and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Trump Names Mick Mulvaney Acting Chief of Staff
articles.snippet: In Mr. Mulvaney, President Trump chose a hard-line conservative and former congressman with a deep understanding of how Congress works and a personal chemistry with Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: In Mr. Mulvaney, President Trump chose a hard-line conservative and former congressman with a deep understanding of how Congress works and a personal chemistry with Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump announced on Friday that he had selected Mick Mulvaney, his budget director, to serve as acting White House chief of staff, putting a halt — at least for now — to his consideration of a parade of possible candidates, including several who turned him down, to take over one of the most important positions in the federal government.
articles.byline: By Michael Tackett and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Star Economist at Harvard Faces Sexual Harassment Complaints
articles.snippet: Roland Fryer’s ascent in the economics field was swift. Now he is embroiled in investigations into his workplace behavior.
articles.abstract: Roland Fryer’s ascent in the economics field was swift. Now he is embroiled in investigations into his workplace behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Before he turned 40, Roland G. Fryer Jr. had earned tenure at Harvard, received a MacArthur “genius” grant and won the most prestigious award for young American economists. He stoked a national debate by concluding that police officers show no bias in the shootings of black men.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Johnson & Johnson Feared Baby Powder’s Possible Asbestos Link for Years
articles.snippet: Johnson & Johnson says its product is safe. But asbestos, a carcinogen that can exist underground near talc, was a concern inside the company for decades.
articles.abstract: Johnson & Johnson says its product is safe. But asbestos, a carcinogen that can exist underground near talc, was a concern inside the company for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: The memos were concise and direct.
articles.byline: By Roni Caryn Rabin and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Investors Have Nowhere to Hide as Stocks, Bonds and Commodities All Tumble
articles.snippet: For the first time in decades, every major investment has fared poorly. The question is whether trouble in the markets will undermine economic growth.
articles.abstract: For the first time in decades, every major investment has fared poorly. The question is whether trouble in the markets will undermine economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks? Messy. Bonds? Meh. Commodities? Not pretty.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips

articles.headline: Ryan Zinke, Face of Trump Environmental Rollbacks, Is Leaving Interior Department
articles.snippet: Mr. Zinke is the latest Trump administration official to exit his position facing questions of ethical conflict.
articles.abstract: Mr. Zinke is the latest Trump administration official to exit his position facing questions of ethical conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, a key figure in President Trump’s sweeping plan to reshape the nation’s environmental framework, resigned under pressure on Saturday as he faces numerous ethics investigations into his business dealings, travel and policy decisions.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: As the Trumps Dodged Taxes, Their Tenants Paid a Price
articles.snippet: A phony business the Trumps created to siphon wealth from their empire drove up the rent for thousands living in their buildings.
articles.abstract: A phony business the Trumps created to siphon wealth from their empire drove up the rent for thousands living in their buildings.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were collateral damage as Donald J. Trump and his siblings dodged inheritance taxes and gained control of their father’s fortune: thousands of renters in an empire of unassuming red-brick buildings scattered across Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.
articles.byline: By Russ Buettner and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: How McKinsey Has Helped Raise the Stature of Authoritarian Governments
articles.snippet: At a time when democracies and their basic values are increasingly under attack, the iconic American company has sometimes served clients in ways that directly counter American interests.
articles.abstract: At a time when democracies and their basic values are increasingly under attack, the iconic American company has sometimes served clients in ways that directly counter American interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year’s McKinsey & Company retreat in China was one to remember.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Ruling Striking Down Obamacare Moves Health Debate to Center Stage
articles.snippet: A Texas judge’s ruling that the Affordable Care Act is unconstitutional may not stand, but it will elevate health care as a pressing topic in a divided Washington.
articles.abstract: A Texas judge’s ruling that the Affordable Care Act is unconstitutional may not stand, but it will elevate health care as a pressing topic in a divided Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The decision by a federal judge in Texas to strike down all of the Affordable Care Act has thrust the volatile debate over health care onto center stage in a newly divided capital, imperiling the insurance coverage of millions of Americans while delivering a possible policy opening to Democrats.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Robert Pear and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Twist in Green Beret’s Extraordinary Story: Trump’s Intervention After Murder Charges
articles.snippet: The Army major has admitted shooting an Afghan man believed to be a bomb maker in 2010, in a case that has become a cause among some conservatives.
articles.abstract: The Army major has admitted shooting an Afghan man believed to be a bomb maker in 2010, in a case that has become a cause among some conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The long and winding case of Maj. Mathew L. Golsteyn had all the elements of a story that would seize President Trump’s attention. A Green Beret charged by the Army in the killing of a man linked to the Taliban. Thorny questions about America’s longstanding entanglement in Afghanistan. And a Fox News program that lauded the officer as a war hero.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Michael Tackett and Taimoor Shah

articles.headline: China’s Detention Camps for Muslims Turn to Forced Labor
articles.snippet: Mounting evidence suggests ethnic minorities caught in the mass internment drive in Xinjiang are being assigned to new factories making clothes.
articles.abstract: Mounting evidence suggests ethnic minorities caught in the mass internment drive in Xinjiang are being assigned to new factories making clothes.
articles.lead_paragraph: KASHGAR, China — Muslim inmates from internment camps in far western China hunched over sewing machines, in row after row. They were among hundreds of thousands who had been detained and spent month after month renouncing their religious convictions. Now the government was showing them on television as models of repentance, earning good pay — and political salvation — as factory workers.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Austin Ramzy

articles.headline: Netflix’s Movie Blitz Takes Aim at Hollywood’s Heart
articles.snippet: “Roma” is just the start of the company’s film plans. Traditional studios and multiplex chains are wondering if the strategy will cause people to skip theaters.
articles.abstract: “Roma” is just the start of the company’s film plans. Traditional studios and multiplex chains are wondering if the strategy will cause people to skip theaters.
articles.lead_paragraph: As hundreds of movie buffs waited in line to see Alfonso Cuarón’s “Roma” at the Telluride Film Festival in August, an S.U.V. rolled up and a tall, tanned man wearing sunglasses stepped out. He smiled and waved before breezing into the theater with his entourage.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Nashville’s Star Rises as Midsize Cities Break Into Winners and Losers
articles.snippet: Nashville and others are thriving thanks to a mix of luck, astute political choices and well-timed investments, while cities like Birmingham, Ala., fall behind.
articles.abstract: Nashville and others are thriving thanks to a mix of luck, astute political choices and well-timed investments, while cities like Birmingham, Ala., fall behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Forty years ago, Nashville and Birmingham, Ala., were peers. Two hundred miles apart, the cities anchored metropolitan areas of just under one million people each and had a similar number of jobs paying similar wages.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman

articles.headline: A Shutdown Looms. Can the G.O.P. Get Lawmakers to Show Up to Vote?
articles.snippet: Vanquished and retiring members have been skipping votes, and House Republican leaders are unsure whether they will ever return.
articles.abstract: Vanquished and retiring members have been skipping votes, and House Republican leaders are unsure whether they will ever return.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just days before a deadline to avert a partial government shutdown, President Trump, Democratic leaders and the Republican-controlled Congress are at a stalemate over the president’s treasured border wall. But House Republican leaders are also confronting a more mundane and awkward problem: Their vanquished and retiring members are sick and tired of Washington and don’t want to show up anymore to vote.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Facebook’s Version of YouTube Takes Shape With Pranksters, Magicians and Cartoons
articles.snippet: The tech giant sees Facebook Watch, with its rising number of videos from internet stars, as a key to future growth.
articles.abstract: The tech giant sees Facebook Watch, with its rising number of videos from internet stars, as a key to future growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 20-something magician performing on the streets of Thailand and Jamaica. Three Australian brothers who shock bystanders with devious pranks. A conservative commentator in Mississippi who rants about America’s priorities from his car.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Tech Workers Got Paid in Company Stock. They Used It to Agitate for Change.
articles.snippet: Workers at tech companies like Amazon are starting to use the stock grants that they were paid to turn the tables on their employers.
articles.abstract: Workers at tech companies like Amazon are starting to use the stock grants that they were paid to turn the tables on their employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley technology firms are known for giving stock to their workers, a form of compensation that often helps employees feel invested in their companies.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger

articles.headline: More Powerful Than a Russian Troll Army: The National Enquirer
articles.snippet: Now that the supermarket tabloid has admitted to prosecutors that it did political dirty work for Donald Trump, here’s a look at its unlikely power.
articles.abstract: Now that the supermarket tabloid has admitted to prosecutors that it did political dirty work for Donald Trump, here’s a look at its unlikely power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most powerful print publication in America might just be The National Enquirer. It functioned as a dirty-tricks shop for Donald J. Trump in 2016, which would have been the stuff of farce — the ultimate tabloid backs the ultimate tabloid candidate — if it hadn’t accomplished its goal.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: France’s Far Right Sees Gold in Yellow Vest Movement
articles.snippet: National Front leaders are trying to turn protests that have left much of France in upheaval to their purposes. But it may be a double-edged sword.
articles.abstract: National Front leaders are trying to turn protests that have left much of France in upheaval to their purposes. But it may be a double-edged sword.
articles.lead_paragraph: HÉNIN-BEAUMONT, France — While security forces under the control of France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, have deployed tear gas, water cannons and mass arrests to quell sometimes violent demonstrations across the country, “Yellow Vest” protesters in northern France have found an unlikely sanctuary: under the wing of a far-right mayor who has made his career railing against disorder.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: Wall Street Hits New 2018 Lows as Fed Decision Looms Over Markets
articles.snippet: Stocks slumped through the afternoon, with the S&P 500 at its lowest point for the year and most sectors affected by the sell-off.
articles.abstract: Stocks slumped through the afternoon, with the S&P 500 at its lowest point for the year and most sectors affected by the sell-off.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street notched a new low for the year on Monday, as worries about the economy continued to dog investors ahead of a crucial Federal Reserve decision on interest rates later this week.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips

articles.headline: New Google Campus Accelerates Tech’s March Into New York
articles.snippet: Google said it planned a $1 billion campus just south of the West Village that would enable it to double its local work force over a decade.
articles.abstract: Google said it planned a $1 billion campus just south of the West Village that would enable it to double its local work force over a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: As West Coast companies storm into New York, they are reshaping the city’s neighborhoods and changing its identity from a hub of finance, fashion and media to one increasingly centered on technology.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Winnie Hu and J. David Goodman

articles.headline: Russian 2016 Influence Operation Targeted African-Americans on Social Media
articles.snippet: Two reports commissioned by the Senate Intelligence Committee take a deeper look at the fake social media accounts used by Russia in the American election.
articles.abstract: Two reports commissioned by the Senate Intelligence Committee take a deeper look at the fake social media accounts used by Russia in the American election.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian influence campaign on social media in the 2016 election made an extraordinary effort to target African-Americans, used an array of tactics to try to suppress turnout among Democratic voters and unleashed a blizzard of activity on Instagram that rivaled or exceeded its posts on Facebook, according to a report produced for the Senate Intelligence Committee.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Former Michael Flynn Business Associates Indicted in Turkey Lobbying Case
articles.snippet: The indictment is evidence of a crackdown growing from the inquiry by Robert S. Mueller III, who has investigated foreign money devised to manipulate decision-making in Washington.
articles.abstract: The indictment is evidence of a crackdown growing from the inquiry by Robert S. Mueller III, who has investigated foreign money devised to manipulate decision-making in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Two former business associates of Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, have been indicted as part of a federal investigation into Turkey’s secret 2016 lobbying campaign to pressure the United States to expel a rival of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Mark Mazzetti
